descriptionSet.description: On this image, a calender from 1954, we can see Sita pointing towards something, as her sons Luv and Kush, practice their archery skills. One of the sons takes aim with his bow and arrow, while another watches. Sita is wearing a yellow sari while her sons wear dhotis. All three of them have flowers in their hair and a garland around their neck. A fawn sits at Sita's feet. They sit under a tree and a waterfall can be seen in the background. The image is framed with decorative designs and an advertisement for products by "Imperial Chemical Products".

inscription.text: Madura South India Corporation Ltd., Post Box No. 1823. No. 20, Govindappa Naick Street, G. T. Madras.
Branches:- Ahmedabad, Alleppey, Amritsar, Bombay, Calcutta, Delhi, Indore, Kanpur, Madras.

description-en: On this image, a calender from 1954, we can see Sita pointing towards something, as her sons Luv and Kush, practice their archery skills. One of the sons takes aim with his bow and arrow, while another watches. Sita is wearing a yellow sari while her sons wear dhotis. All three of them have flowers in their hair and a garland around their neck. A fawn sits at Sita's feet. They sit under a tree and a waterfall can be seen in the background. The image is framed with decorative designs and an advertisement for products by "Imperial Chemical Products". (gs/sp)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: Sita training her sons in archery. The name of Imperial Chemicals Industries frames the picture, headquartered in Ballard Estate, the European business district in Bombay. Presumably, a prestigious corporation could afford to publicly identify itself with mythological imagery in 1954. Up-market business’s public sponsorship of such imagery is scarce today, by comparison. (Arvind Rajagopal)(gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: This image presents a more familiar devotional scene with calendars advertising the company’s products. Aestheticization does not necessarily displace devotionalism, but co-exists with it, as English multinational corporations qualify their commitment to “realism” by a demotic religious idiom convenient for the market. We might be tempted to call this a process of partial secularization accomplished through market-based religious imagery. But “religion” here does not correlate with a unified authority such as with the church. There is no single religious authority, on the contrary, whether within Hinduism or Islam (these examples are from the former, clearly). Nor is there a domain that is demarcated from the religious, whether as profane or as secular. Similarly if the outcome is partial secularization, it is achieved not through the privatization of religion, but by its enlarged public presence. (Arvind Rajagopal)(gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: In this image, we see that Hindu imagery accompanies the names of businesses and the text above and below frames and surrounds the images of the gods. The relationship suggested between the god images and commerce is a close one. (Arvind Rajagopal)(gs)
related literature: Rajagopal, Arvind 2010. "The Commodity Image in the (Post) Colony" http://www.tasveergharindia.net/cmsdesk/essay/100/index_1.html (18.1.2011)(gs)
Rajagopal, Arvind 2010. "The Commodity Image in the (Post) Colony" http://www.tasveergharindia.net/cmsdesk/essay/100/index_1.html (18.1.2011)
Calendar poster is torn from bottom but frame is good.
